Authors:
Dean C. Adams, Joseph M. Craine, Lynn G Clark, Timothy J.
Gallaher, Sean Vincent Burke, Phillip C. Klahs, Lakshmi Attigala,
William P. Wysocki, Melvin R Duvall, Emma Sherratt
Title:
The Role of Leaf Shape, Size and Vein Architecture Evolution
in the Ecological Diversification of Grasses (Poaceae)
Keywords:
Adaptation, C4 photosynthesis, geometric morphometrics,
grasslands, macroecology, phylogeny, vein architecture
Abstract:
Grasses emerged from forest ecosystems into open habitats
and some lineages subsequently expanded into water-limiting regions
following the evolution of C4 photosynthesis. These transitions were
accompanied by distinctive variation in leaf morphology and anatomy. We
investigated these macroevolutionary changes in leaf shape, size and
vein architecture as putative adaptations to light regime, climate and
photosynthetic pathway using a new time-calibrated phylogeny as a
framework for analyses. Leaf shape was found to closely track light
regime. The grass leaf adapts to light regime by varying leaf width
without changes in length; however, length and width vary together in
response to moisture availability and solar radiation. An intermediate
leaf shape associated with partial-shade habitats (i.e.Â forest gaps or
margins) represents an important transitional state for habitat shifts
to full sun or deep shade associated with the evolution of linear leaves
and ovate leaves respectively. Inter-bundle distance variation is
reduced among C4 taxa indicating stabilizing selection achieved by the
insertion of veins or an increase in bundle-related tissues. The
relative strength of these two mechanisms is strongly influenced by the
leaf width of the C3 ancestors of C4 lineages indicating historical
effects of habitat and climate on the development of functional C4
anatomy.
